Tom got a Mr. Potato Head for his birthday. It came with 3 hairstyles, 2 sets of eyebrows, 1 pair of googly eyes, 2 sets of ears, and 2 sets of lips, a pair of regular shoes, and a bonus pair of clown shoes. If a complete Mr. Potato Head personality includes eyebrows, eyes, ears, lips, shoes and optionally hair, how many different wacky personalities can Tom come up with? Note that Mr. Potato Head can be bald.

Note: You cannot "mix and match".  For example, you cannot take the left eyebrow from one pair and the right eyebrow from the other pair.

ost_step.1: To create a unique personality, each part needs to be chosen independently. Thus, the choice of eye color or shoe type does not affect what else he could choose; it simply adds more options available.   Step 2: There are three ways of styling potatoes face -- no style, normal size head shape/style , small ear hat combo .  Each requires choices among multiple independent items as follows :    - Eyes     * One set out of 1 possibility* Two pairs of lips     *One way or another.* Shoe Type        * Regular sneakers       * Clown onesies*. These counts do not include optional hair styles since having any amount would mean creating new possibilities. Hence our count comes to...      Combinations possible=Eye Choices x Lip Choseces X Shoe Options     =1×2×2=.         That makes exactly **four** distinct combinations without regard to appearance beyond whether someone was wearing those parts or had them attached directly onto themselves! And because some people might prefer certain looks over others when making decisions about clothing like hats etc., let’s just assume every combination matters equally here…so four times seven equals twenty eight variations overall.(Including both bald &

direct_answer.text:
To calculate the number of different wacky personalities Tom can come up with for Mr. Potato Head, considering that mixing and matching individual features such as eyebrows, eyes, ears, lips, shoes doesn't matter but changing facial expressions using various heads shapes and sizes does, follow these steps:

Step 1: Determine potential appearances based on heads and accessories provided.
There are essentially six main components contributing to formulating characters – Facial Expression, Hair Style, Left Eyebrow Set, Right Eyebrow Set, Lips Set, Nose Shape, Ear Pads, Mouthpiece, Footwear Variety:
Facial Expressions: No Change ("Neutral"), Small Hat Accessory ('Small') | Total Possible Appearances due to Face Designation: 2
Hair Styles: Bald ('Bald'), Normal Size ('Regular'), Short 'Short', Long 'Long', With Ears Attached('Wearing Telescope'). |Total Possible Appears Due to Hairstyle Specification: 5 [Exclude short and long]
Left/Right Side Eyebrows Sets Available: Yes /

Tom got a Mr. Potato Head for his birthday. It came with 3 hairstyles, 2 sets of eyebrows, 1 pair of googly eyes, 2 sets of ears, and 2 sets of lips, a pair of regular shoes, and a bonus pair of clown shoes. If a complete Mr. Potato Head personality includes eyebrows, eyes, ears, lips, shoes and optionally hair, how many different wacky personalities can Tom come up with? Note that Mr. Potato Head can be bald.

Note: You cannot "mix and match".  For example, you cannot take the left eyebrow from one pair and the right eyebrow from the other pair.

1.subquestion: In how many ways can he put together three items (eyes, mouth, shoe)?

subanswer.text: He can select any item as eyes, so there're 4 options; after selecting eyes, either pick any remaining eye or none at all resulting in 3 possibilities; similarly, among six pairs of feet, regardless if he chooses which foot goes where because they don’t have distinguishing features – only color matters! So total combinations here would just depend upon whether choosing boot/shoes set A & B simultaneously=$\binom{4}{1}\times\binom{3}{1}\times\binom{6}{1}=72$. The answer is $72$.

2.subquestion: With respect to non-hair items mentioned above, excluding combination choices like those made while answering Q#5.1 , how much variation exists now before considering variations due solely using available heads without putting pieces back ?

subanswer.text: Excluding head piece variability but focusing only onto body parts leads towards another calculation involving permutations taken over repetition allowed scenarios since some configurations might look identical despite having distinct arrangements eg.(AABBCC)(AAAACC), etc .Thus giving rise count such instances equals factorial division summed across individual groups thus coming down ultimately leading toward simplifying further getting simplified form representing final output obtained post deriving formula incorporating every single constraint imposed till current stage being considered viz:(Total Count)=$(3+2)*((4*3)+(4*(4!/2!) * ((2!/(1!(2-1)!))^(sum_of_groups))) ;total possible arrangement=(ProductOfBodyPartsChoices)/(PermutationWithRepetitionOnEyeGroup);So Final OutputPostDerivativeInclusionForCurrentConstraintImposedToThisStage=$(3+(2**2))\Bigl(\biggl[\tfrac{(4)(3)}{1}+(4)\Biggr]\Bigr/\biggl[2!\bigr/](1![2-(1)!)]^{sum\_of\_group)=\dfrac {[(4)(3)(8)}]{2!} =\text{ }\\ \\$$\therefore TotalCount=[(3+\color{#c00}{\underline{4}})}\Bigg[\Big\{\frac{(4)(3)}{\color{#c00}{1}}\ +\frac{4}{(2)}(2)^{2}\Big\}\bigg]$ This yields our required solution counting valid unique configuration possibility including optional use case within boundary constraints namely:- **NonHairVariationBeforeCombinationSelectionAndExcludingAnyFurtherMixMatchOptionsWhichMayYieldSimilarLookButDifferentConfigurationInstancesConsideringHeadPartAssignmentAsWellNotAccountingNorIgnoringOptionalUseCaseRequirementRelatedOnlyTopicWasDiscussedTillPresentPoint######

ost_step.1: Thus, based on above steps it comes out as : There exist $$\left\{ (4 \cdot 3) + (4 \cdot 4) - 1 \right\} / \left[2! / (1!(2 - 1)!)\right] ^ {\left(3 + 2\right)}$$ ways when excluding shoe choices i.e., $$72.$$ After considering both Shoe Options finally result becomes $$144.$$ Hence using Permutation Formula ($nPr$) ,number of Personalities formed taking into consideration non selection cases also become equal to 144. Finally Solution Result turns Out To Be:$144.$ As mentioned earlier due care was made while solving problem without mixing&matching rules violation hence no confusion arises regarding same looking yet diverse variations occurred during derivation process itself underlining fact making sure each decision tree path chosen lead us eventually arriving correct conclusion even though seemed intricate initially thanks again :) Happy Coding !! So total combinations here would just depend upon whether choosing boot/shoes set A & B simultaneously=$\binom{4}{1}\times\binom{3}{1}\times\binom{6}{1}=72$. The answer is $72$.

Tom got a Mr. Potato Head for his birthday. It came with 3 hairstyles, 2 sets of eyebrows, 1 pair of googly eyes, 2 sets of ears, and 2 sets of lips, a pair of regular shoes, and a bonus pair of clown shoes. If a complete Mr. Potato Head personality includes eyebrows, eyes, ears, lips, shoes and optionally hair, how many different wacky personalities can Tom come up with? Note that Mr. Potato Head can be bald.

Note: You cannot "mix and match".  For example, you cannot take the left eyebrow from one pair and the right eyebrow from the other pair.

These counts do not include optional hair styles since having any amount would mean creating new possibilities. Hence our count comes to...      Combinations possible=Eye Choices x Lip Choseces X Shoe Options     =1×2×2=.         That makes exactly **four** distinct combinations without regard to appearance beyond whether someone was wearing those parts or had them attached directly onto themselves!
